pullRequest.body:
Introduced `Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Simultaneous.lean` as a receptacle for results concerning simultaneous eigenspace decomposition results for tuples of commuting symmetric operators on (finite-dimensional) Hilbert space. 

Includes decomposition of finite-dimensional Hilbert space as internal direct sum of simultaneous eigenspaces of a commuting pair of symmetric operators.

Co-Authored by: Jack Cheverton <jt18chev@siena.edu>

Co-Authored by: Samyak Dhar Tuladhar <sd10tula@siena.edu>

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

</details>

Note: there is also [Module.End.iSup_genEigenspace_restrict_eq_top](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Eigenspace/Triangularizable.html#Module.End.iSup_genEigenspace_restrict_eq_top), so really you want the result I mentioned about generalized eigenspaces of symmetric operators.

Great! Thanks for these. Will work on them.

> <https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15012#discussion_r1735340934>

> +    rw [â† Submodule.orthogonal_eq_bot_iff]

> +    (eigenspace_invariant_of_commute hAB Î±))

I've had a lot of input in this.

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by j-loreaux.
Good catch, thanks

Great; thanks!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10637749889/job/29492255072)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10637749889/job/29492254827)
Can you merge master into this? The variable inclusion mechanism has changed in the latest version of Lean and might lead to breakage here, so it's easier to do this before trying to merge.
This is a first pass.
After you address these, I'll have another look where I really dig into the proofs myself.
After these changes I think it will be ready for the maintainer queue.
Can you merge master into this? The variable inclusion mechanism has changed in the latest version of Lean and might lead to breakage here, so it's easier to do this before trying to merge.

I know they're the same, but I'm suggesting this change because we don't actually assume `[CompleteSpace E]` here.
```suggestion
of symmetric operators on a finite-dimensional inner product space.
```

I think this name is too long otherwise. Note also, we're beginning to use dot notation even if there are no arguments with that type as input, because we can still use it with the *expected type* dot notation.
```suggestion
* `DirectSum.IsInternal.eigenspaces_of_commuting_symmetric_pair` establishes that
```
This is not detailed enough to explain what you mean. It sounds like you just want to use `Classical.choice` to pick a basis, but I think that's not what you intend.

Maybe I remove this, as I don't really know what I intend, either. I think you have an idea of what this is, though...so I will go and look at your comments and maybe update this accordingly. I don't want to forget what you suggested, and so wanted a reminder here...
I stole something from a communication we had earlier and put it in place of this comment as a reminder. If it is still unclear, I can remove the to do altogether.

You should just be able to use the notation `âŸªx, yâŸ«_ð•œ` throughout without needing to introduce local notation. If you copied this from other files, it's probably just a vestige from before we had the notation I mentioned working reliably for `RCLike ð•œ`.
When I omitted it before, something broke. Let me check again...
Note the `_ð•œ` in my notation.
Everything works now, so I can resolve this.

This should be defeq, but I'm not sure it's actually better, so I'm not necessarily advocating for it yet. Mainly I'm putting this here as a reminder to myself that it's something to consider.
```suggestion
    (hAB : Commute A B)
```
Yes...somehow this doesn't work. I was wondering why that was when we originally wrote this, because checking...these are, I think, definitionally equal. EDIT: you said this...

The name makes it seem like the eigenspace for `A` is invariant for `A`, which is obviously true, but it's not the statement here. The name needs to convey that it's for the other operator. Maybe `eigenspace_invariant_of_commute` (especially with the `Commute A B` suggestion above).
Need to sort the commute issue...
Especially since the statement of this theorem is hard to parse, a docstring which explains the statement in human-friendly terms would be nice.
Here's an attempt.
docstrings are nice. :smile:
Point taken!
I realize that I'm shying away from this because it's hard for some of the technical results. All the more reason to do it!!

This is half of your main result, it should definitely get a docstring. Also, I understand the temptation to use the word `simultaneous`, but I would use `inf` because it matches the statement better.
This is the other half of your main result, it should definitely get a docstring. Same comment about `simultaneous` versus `inf`, and also I don't think you mean `pairwise`.
Oh.. I DEFINITELY don't mean pairwise...
Let's not introduce random changes to the diff.
Can I get rid of this?
Put the blank line back in.
ditto
How can I remove these?
remove the blank line

You can get this for free from [Submodule.inf_genEigenspace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Eigenspace/Basic.html#Submodule.inf_genEigenspace) if you first prove that, for symmetric operators, (a) the restriction to an invariant subspace is symmetric (which we may already have), and (b) the generalized eigenspace is the eigenspace.

We want both of those, so you might as well find / add them. That way we don't duplicate the proof.
Fantastic! This is good to know.
This worked, especially well if I reversed the order of the inf...no need even to prove (b) as it follows by rfl and Lean sees this.

Why don't you just have `(Î³ : ð•œ)` as an argument, instead of viewing this as a function equality?

Also, I would call this `eigenspace_restrict_eigenspace_eq_inf`, or something like that.
```suggestion
theorem invariant_subspace_inf_eigenspace_eq_restrict' : (fun (Î³ : ð•œ) â†¦
    Submodule.map (Submodule.subtype (eigenspace A Î±)) (eigenspace (B.restrict
    (eigenspace_invariant_of_commute hAB Î±)) Î³))
    = (fun (Î³ : ð•œ) â†¦ (eigenspace B Î³ âŠ“ eigenspace A Î±)) := by
```

In my mind, the more natural statement here would be `â¨† Î³, eigenspace B Î³ âŠ“ eigenspace A Î± = eigenspace A Î±`. Is there are particular reason that statemnet is bad for your purposes?

In either case, the naming is a problem because `eigenspace` is not mentioned.

For some reason, yes. When we originally tried this (we used the natural statement you mentioned) there were some issues in resolving the `\top` to that eigenspace. Things worked with the \top, though. Maybe this is another situation about transparency?

possibly with `_eq_top` appended.
```suggestion
theorem iSup_iSup_eigenspace_inf_eigenspace :
    (â¨† (Î± : ð•œ), (â¨† (Î³ : ð•œ), (eigenspace B Î³ âŠ“ eigenspace A Î±))) = âŠ¤ := by
```

This matches the statement better.
```suggestion
theorem orthogonalFamily_eigenspace_inf_eigenspace :
```

Or possibly: `DirectSum.IsInternal.simultaneous_eigenspace_of_commute`
```suggestion
theorem DirectSum.IsInternal.eigenspace_inf_eigenspace :
```

Normally we put all the type variables first
```suggestion
variable {ð•œ E : Type*} [RCLike ð•œ]
variable [NormedAddCommGroup E] [InnerProductSpace ð•œ E] [FiniteDimensional ð•œ E]
```

style
```suggestion
    comp_apply B A v, â† map_smul, â† map_sub, hv, map_zero] at *
```

I don't think you want the function version. Just pass `Î³` as a parameter, like below. Note that I have also reversed the direction of the equality, and we can simplify the name that way.
```lean
open Submodule in
/-- The intersection of eigenspaces of commuting selfadjoint operators is equal to the eigenspace of
one operator restricted to the eigenspace of the other, which is an invariant subspace because the
operators commute. -/
theorem eigenspace_inf_eigenspace (Î± Î³ : ð•œ) :
    eigenspace A Î± âŠ“ eigenspace B Î³ = map (Submodule.subtype (eigenspace A Î±))
      (eigenspace (B.restrict (eigenspace_invariant_of_commute hAB Î±)) Î³) :=
  (eigenspace A Î±).inf_genEigenspace _ _ (k := 1)
```

As I mentioned before, this name doesn't work because it doesn't mention `eigenspace` anywhere. But additionally, it's nicer if you *don't* work in the subtype, but that means you need to do slightly more work in the proof.
```suggestion
then the supremum of intersection of eigenspaces is precisely the non-indexed eigenspace. -/
theorem iSup_eigenspace_inf_eigenspace :
    (â¨† Î³, eigenspace A Î± âŠ“ eigenspace B Î³) = eigenspace A Î± := by
  conv_rhs => rw [â† (eigenspace A Î±).map_subtype_top]
  simp only [eigenspace_inf_eigenspace hAB, â† Submodule.map_iSup]
  congr 1
  rw [â† Submodule.orthogonal_eq_bot_iff]
  exact orthogonalComplement_iSup_eigenspaces_eq_bot <|
    hB.restrict_invariant <| eigenspace_invariant_of_commute hAB Î±
```

I wonder if I can shorten this further using the generalized eigenspace result. I tried a little but wasn't successful. One silly question: why did you specify the depth for `congr` here? I wouldn't have thought to do this.

I don't see an obvious way to use generalized eigenspaces further here.

When `congr` or `convert` don't do what I expect / want (or produce a million goals), it's generally because they have gone too deep. So, if it doesn't do exactly what I think it should, I immediately go for limiting depth. Sometimes this makes me realize I was being stupid, and I *shouldn't* have expected them to work. Other times, limiting the depth is exactly what's needed.

see, you really did want to pass `Î³` as a parameter in the earlier version. Does this make sense?
```suggestion
/-- If A and B are commuting symmetric operators acting on a finite dimensional inner product space,
then the simultaneous eigenspaces of A and B exhaust the space. -/
theorem iSup_iSup_eigenspace_inf_eigenspace_eq_top :
    (â¨† Î±, â¨† Î³, eigenspace A Î± âŠ“ eigenspace B Î³) = âŠ¤ := by
  simpa [iSup_eigenspace_inf_eigenspace hB hAB] using
    Submodule.orthogonal_eq_bot_iff.mp <| hA.orthogonalComplement_iSup_eigenspaces_eq_bot
```

cleanup. I think this is slightly nicer because it's more symmetric.
```suggestion
    OrthogonalFamily ð•œ (fun i : ð•œ Ã— ð•œ â†¦ (eigenspace A i.2 âŠ“ eigenspace B i.1 : Submodule ð•œ E))
    (fun i => (eigenspace A i.2 âŠ“ eigenspace B i.1).subtypeâ‚—áµ¢) :=
  OrthogonalFamily.of_pairwise fun i j hij v âŸ¨hv1 , hv2âŸ© â†¦ by
    obtain (hâ‚ | hâ‚‚) : i.1 â‰  j.1 âˆ¨ i.2 â‰  j.2 := by rwa [Ne.eq_def, Prod.ext_iff, not_and_or] at hij
    all_goals intro w âŸ¨hw1, hw2âŸ©
    Â· exact hB.orthogonalFamily_eigenspaces.pairwise hâ‚ hv2 w hw2
    Â· exact hA.orthogonalFamily_eigenspaces.pairwise hâ‚‚ hv1 w hw1
```

hanging `,` in the docstring, and use of dot notation in the proof. Also, note that the previous name was overly namespaced, and didn't give you anything you would want (like dot notation for `DirectSum.IsInternal`. I think this name is better.
```suggestion
/-- Given a commuting pair of symmetric linear operators on a finite dimensional inner product
space, the space decomposes as an internal direct sum of simultaneous eigenspaces of these
operators. -/
theorem directSum_isInteral_of_commute :
    DirectSum.IsInternal (fun (i : ð•œ Ã— ð•œ) â†¦ (eigenspace A i.2 âŠ“ eigenspace B i.1)):= by
  apply (orthogonalFamily_eigenspace_inf_eigenspace hA hB).isInternal_iff.mpr
```

This needs to be updated to reflect the new name.
```suggestion
* `LinearMap.IsSymmetric.directSum_isInternal_of_commute` establishes that
```
Oops!!

"Simultaneous", while I've heard the term used before, I think only makes sense in the context of *diagonalization*, and, strictly speaking, there is no diagonalization here. (in the sense that we don't get a collection of eigenvalues and eigenvectors.). Also, don't focus on pairs here, since you want to add the version for finite collections of commuting operators shortly.
```suggestion
/-! # Joint eigenspaces of commuting symmetric operators
```
I think we should change the name to `JointEigenspace` for the reasons outlined above.

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.JointEigenspace
```

```suggestion
theorem eigenspace_invariant_of_commute (Î± : ð•œ) :
    âˆ€ v âˆˆ eigenspace A Î±, B v âˆˆ eigenspace A Î± := by
```

Also, having explicit arguments in a variable command somewhere above (i.e. `hA`, `hB` and `hAB` in this case) is generally discouraged, because then we can't tell how to actually use the lemma just by looking at the lemma statement.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: (Analysis.InnerProductSpace) Decomposition of Finite-Dimensional Inner Product Space as Direct Sum of Simultaneous Eigenspaces of Commuting Symmetric Operators
